questions.text: The Image shown below is seen in deficiency of ______
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic Casal's necklace pattern, seen in Pellagra, which occur due to deficiency of  Vitamin B3 (niacin).

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows rotavirus which is wheel shaped.

 

Other options:

Adenovirus - Space vehicle shaped

Astrovirus - Star shaped

Tobacco mosaic virus - Rod shaped

questions.text: The following patch on the cornea is associated with infection by ______:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Salmon patch appearance of cornea.

Salmon patch appearance of cornea is classically associated with syphilitic infection.

It is due to deep vascularization of cornea consisting of radial bundle of brush-like vessels

Stages of interstital keratitis in Congenital syphilis :

  • Initial progressive – Ground glass appearance
  • Florid stage – Salmon patch appearance
  • Stage of Regression – Ghost vessels

questions.text: The following sign in USG is depictive of
questions.solution:
• The given USG shows the double decidual sign surrounding the gestational sac and is defined by the decidua parietalis and the decidua capsularis.
  • The double decidual sac sign differentiates normal pregnancy from pseudogestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: The marked area given in the sleep polysomnography is of ______
questions.solution:
The marked area in the given polysomnography represents REM sleep.

The three zones in the given image represent EOG, EEG and EMG, respectively.

The following table helps identify the state of wakefulness from the graph :

    EEG EOG EMG
Active state   Fast   +   +
REM sleep  Mixed    +   -
NREM sleep   Slow   -   +

 

In the marked area,

  • EOG shows Positive activity
  • EEG shows Mixed waves
  • EMG shows Minimal activity

This is characteristic of REM sleep.

questions.text: The given image is of a patient in whom mastoidectomy is done. Identify the lateral semi-circular canal:
questions.solution:
The structure marked as ‘B’ in the given image represents the lateral (horizontal) semi-circular canal. The tympanic (horizontal) segment of the facial nerve lies below the lateral horizontal semicircular canal. 

Other markings represent:

A: Superior semicircular canal (SSC)

C: Posterior semicircular canal (PSC)

D: Incus

The semicircular canals are positioned in the superior part of the mastoid region. These canals are situated adjacent to the middle ear, with the lateral semicircular canal being the nearest to the middle ear. The superior and posterior canals share a common crescent-shaped space in between. The one that lies in close proximity to the lateral semicircular canal is the posterior semicircular canal.

The semicircular canals are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum. They are 3 semicircular canals, lateral (horizontal), superior (anterior), and posterior. They lie in planes at right angles to one another.

Stimulation of semicircular canals produces nystagmus. The nystagmus is rotatory from the superior canal, horizontal from the horizontal canal, and vertical from the posterior canal.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked in the image _________
questions.solution:
The artery marked in the image is superior cerebellar artery.

The superior cerebellar artery arises near the distal portion of the basilar artery, immediately before the formation of the posterior cerebral arteries. The superior cerebellar artery supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

Circle of Willis or circulus arteriosus: Large arterial anastomosis that unites the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems. It lies in the subarachnoid space within the basal cisterns that surround the optic chiasma and infundibulum.

The anterior cerebral arteries are derived from the internal carotid arteries and are linked by a small anterior communicating artery.

Posteriorly, the two posterior cerebral arteries are formed by the division of the basilar artery. They are joined to the ipsilateral internal carotid artery by a posterior communicating artery.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is the cause for the effect shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The image depicts Osteonecrosis of jaw, which is a side effect of the Bisphosphonates like Zoledronate.

Side effects of Zoledronate:

  • Nausea, vomiting, bodyache
  • Renal toxicity
  • Osteonecrosis of jaw
  • Hypocalcaemia and seizures
  • Increased risk of bone fractures
  • Bone pain

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given left ventricular pressure-volume curve:
questions.solution:
The ejection fraction as calculated from the above volume pressure curve is 60%.

The ejection fraction is defined as the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke.

Thus, EF = Volume ejected / End diastolic volume × 100

The volume ejected can be obtained, by subtracting the end systolic volume from end diastolic volume. Thus,

EF = End diastolic volume (EDV) − End systolic volume (ESV) / End diastolic volume (EDV) × 100

In the above volume pressure curve of left ventricle,

EDV = 130 ml

ESV = 52 ml

Substituting these values in the above equation we get,

EF = (130 − 52 / 130) × 100

 = (3 / 5) × 100

 = 0.6 × 100

 = 60%

Related information:

The ejection fraction is a valuable index of the ventricular function. It is measured by injecting radionuclide-labeled red blood cells and imaging the volume of the blood at the end of diastole and the end of systole (equilibrium radionuclide angiocardiography), or by computed tomography.

The normal left ventricular ejection fraction is 50% to 70%.

In heart failure, ejection fraction may be preserved or reduced,

  • Preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) – also referred to as diastolic heart failure. The heart muscle contracts normally but the ventricles do not relax as they should during ventricular filling (or when the ventricles relax).
  • Reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) – also referred to as systolic heart failure. The heart muscle does not contract effectively and less oxygen-rich blood is pumped out to the body.

LVEF Assessment:

The American college of cardiology (ACC), gives the cardiac function and their corresponding ejection fractions

  • Hyperdynamic = LVEF greater than 70%
  • Normal = LVEF 50% to 70% (midpoint 60%)
  • Mild dysfunction = LVEF 40% to 49% (midpoint 45%)
  • Moderate dysfunction = LVEF 30% to 39% (midpoint 35%)
  • Severe dysfunction = LVEF less than 30%

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic comes to you with a rash over the intertriginous areas, which is more pronounced over his groin.  Wood's lamp examination shows coral pink fluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Coral pink fluorescence on Wood's lamp examination is characteristic of erythrasma.

Erythrasma is a skin infection caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. It is common in diabetics and immunodeficient patients and is associated with obesity, sweating and poor hygiene.

Coral pink fluorescence is due to the production of coproporphyrin III by the bacterium.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: dull blue

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: A patient underwent inguinal hernia repair surgery, during which the nerve marked in the image below was injured.  Which of the following structures does this nerve supply?

choices.text: Skin on lateral aspect of thigh

questions.solution:
The nerve marked in the image is the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2), which can be injured during inguinal hernia repair. Among the given structures, it supplies the cremaster muscle.

Branches of genitofemoral nerve:

  • Genital branch: Innervates cremaster
  • Femoral branch:
    • Skin of the scrotum in males
    • Skin of mons pubis and labium majus in females
    • Anteromedial skin of the thigh

Related Pearl: Lumbar Plexus

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve.

questions.text: True about the circuit given below is _________

choices.text: Also called Jackson Rees modification circuit

questions.solution:
The circuit given in the image is Mapleson A or Magill circuit. It has a low fresh gas flow rate requirement of 1 x minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing of carbon dioxide. Hence, it is considered the best for spontaneous ventilation.

In Mapleson circuits D, E, and F, the amount of fresh gas flow required is 2.5 times a minute ventilation and in mapleson circuits B and C, it is much higher.

Mapleson circuit A is not very useful in controlled ventilation because minute ventilation as high as 20 L/minute (fresh gas flow rate should be greater than 3 times minute ventilation) is needed to prevent rebreathing. Mapleson circuit D is used for controlled ventilation.

 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)



Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: The fracture seen in the X-ray given below is?
questions.solution:
The image shows an oblique fracture in the lower third of the radius with dislocation of distal radio-ulnar joint. So the fracture seen in the X-ray is Galeazzi's fracture.

Galeazzi's fracture is the fracture of the lower third of the radius and the subluxation or dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint. This injury usually happens when one falls on an outstretched hand. The most common clinical feature is tenderness over the distal end of the forearm. 

The aim of treatment for this fracture is to preserve supination and pronation of the forearm. In children, closed reduction is usually enough to achieve perfect reduction. However, in adults, open reduction using a k-wire fixation or compression plating is usually required. It is also important to look for ulnar nerve damage.

Galeazzi's fracture can cause complications such as malunion due to displacement of the fragment. This often results in deformity and limitation in supination and pronation.

Other options: 

Option B: Monteggia fracture is the fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of the proximal radio-ulnar joint and the subluxation of the radiocapitellar joint.

Option C: Smith's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with palmar angulation of the distal bone fragment. It also known as reverse Colle's fracture.

Option D: Colle's fracture is the fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment. 

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: The bodies shown in this image (highlighted) are seen in which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The image shows Call exner bodies which are seen in Granulosa cell tumour.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene is seen in 97% of adult granulosa cell tumors.

Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with granulosa cell tumors. It is used in monitoring patients being treated.

Other options -

Option B: Dysgerminoma is the ovarian counterpart of seminoma. They are unilateral tumors composed of vesicular cells and clear cytoplasm. The tumor cells grow in cords or sheets that are separated by scanty fibrous stroma. They are usually infiltrated by lymphocytes. The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma

Option C: Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa. 

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Krukenberg tumor.

Option D : A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. 

Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus

Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever

Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes

Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency

Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis

Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons

Creola bodies Asthma

questions.text: Accidental ingestion of the insect shown below is associated with which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
The insect is identified as the Spanish fly. Accidental consumption is associated with priapism.

Spanish fly is a winged insect with a length of 2 cm and a breadth of 0.6 cm with greenish-black color and shiny wings. It contains the toxic active principle cantharidin.

The active principle can be absorbed through the skin and all mucosa. On local application to the skin or mucosa, it is associated with redness of skin, and burning pain followed by vesication of the skin. The sequela of cantharides ingestion involves priapism. Features of this poisoning are severe thirst, dysphagia, priapism, genital pain, tenesmus, and convulsions resulting in coma and death. Abortion can occur if the woman is pregnant.

Treatment is symptomatic and if ingested, stomach wash needs to be done along with the administration of demulcents.

Other Options: 

Option A: Acrodynia is seen in chronic mercury poisoning, in which there is pain and pink discoloration of the hands and feet.

Option C: Raindrop pigmentation is a finely mottled brown change on skin flexures, temples, eyelids, and necks seen in arsenic poisoning.

Option D: Magnan’s sign is seen in cocaine addicts where they experience and interpret paraesthesia as the constant movement of a foreign body or bugs under their skin.

questions.text: The following appearance on ERCP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
The given appearance of the fish-eye lesion of the ampulla of Vater on ERCP is characteristic of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). 

Mucin can be seen extruding from the ampulla of Vater, a so-called fish-eye lesion that is virtually diagnostic of IPMN.

Cyst fluid analysis of various pancreatic cystic neoplasms:

Characteristics Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN) Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN)

Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN)
Cytology


 Scant glycogen-rich cells, with positive periodic acid-Schiff stain Sheets and clusters of columnar, mucin-containing cells Tall, columnar, mucin-containing cells

Mucin stain

 Negative Positive Positive
Amylase Low Low High
CEA Low High High

Related Pearl: Cystic Neoplasm of the Pancreas

Characteristics Serous Cystadenoma Mucinous Cystadenoma
Nature Benign Benign, but high risk of malignancy
Epidemiology Common in females (F:M = 2:1) and older age 
Associated with von Hippel Lindau syndrome 		 Most common cystic neoplasm of the pancreas 
Common in perimenopausal females
Usual site

Usually tail of the pancreas, can be uniformly distributed

 Body and tail of the pancreas
Microscopy Microcysts giving a honey-comb appearance Glycogen-rich cells Mucin-producing epithelium
Ovarian-like stroma
Stains positive for estrogen and progesterone
CT Central calcification, with radiating septa giving sunburst appearance.

Solitary cyst with fine septations, surrounded by a rim of calcification.

Eggshell calcification, large tumor size, or a mural nodule are suggestive of malignancy
Cyst fluid analysis

Mucin negative

Low CEA and amylase

Mucin-rich aspirate

High CEA and low amylase
Treatment

Mainly conservative

Resection: If symptomatic or if malignancy is suspected

 Resection (because of risk of malignancy)
Prognosis

Good

 Poor

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and Fluorescein angiography findings of neovascularization are suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).

Neovascularization is a hallmark of PDR. So this rules out Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy-NPDR (Option A,B).

Option C: Birdshot retinochoroidopathy is an idiopathic bilateral chorioretinitis characterized by creamy yellow spots of chorioretinal hypopigmentation resembling a birdshot scatter. It most commonly affects middle aged females who are HLA-A29 positive.

PDR is most common in patients with Type Ⅰ diabetes after a period of 15-20 years and is characterized by proliferation of new vessels at the optic disc (NVD) or elsewhere in the fundus (NVE).

( NVD- neovascularization at the optic disc ; NVE-neovascularization elsewhere in the fundus )

Complications of PDR include recurrent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment and pre retinal hemorrhages.

It is treated by administration of Anti-VEGF drugs followed by pan retinal photocoagulation which destroys the hypoxic retina that has been producing the vasoformative factors responsible for neovascularization.

Duration of diabetes mellitus is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy.

Ophthalmoscopic features of NPDR include:

  • Microaneurysms: due to loss of pericytes around the capillaries
  • Retinal hemorrhages: both superficial (flame shaped) and deep (dot & blot) hemorrhages.
  • Hard exudates: composed of lipoproteins and lipid laden macrophages. They are yellow waxy looking and arranged in clumps or circinate patterns.
  • Cotton wool spots: which are small whitish fluffy lesions which represent areas of nerve infarct.
  • Intra retinal microvascular abnormalities(IRMA): are arteriovenous shunts in retina
  • Venous abnormalities such as beading,looping and dilatation.

The below given image is that of Hard Exudates.

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: Garland Sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
MRI coronal T2 sequence showing hyperintensity along corticospinal tract and corpus callosum forming a ‘Garland pattern'- Seen in ALS

Other options:

  • Huntington’s disease – Box car ventricles
  • Progressive supranuclear palsy – Humming bird sign
  • Multisystem atrophy – Hot cross bun sign

Note : Garland triad, also known as the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign, is a lymph node enlargement pattern which has been described in sarcoidosis.

questions.text: The X-ray below is of a patient who recently underwent a bronchoscopy and has complaints of chest pain. Which of the following would you expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows air in the mediastinum, adjacent to the descending aorta and left common carotid artery. Along with the history of the patient, we can arrive at the diagnosis of pneumomediastinum.

Pneumomediastinum:

The main causes of gas/air in the interstices of the mediastinum are

  1. Alveolar rupture, perforation or
  2. Rupture of esophagus/trachea/bronchi,
  3. Dissection of air from the neck or abdomen into the mediastinum.

Clinical Features include severe substernal chest pain(may or may not radiate to neck and arms) & subcutaneous Emphysema over the suprasternal notch.

The examination may reveal subcutaneous emphysema in the suprasternal notch with Hamman’s sign. Chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis. No treatment is usually required but inhaling high concentrations of oxygen will help absorb the mediastinal air. Needle aspiration can be performed if mediastinal structures are compressed.  

Hamman’s sign:

It can be elicited in pneumomediastinum and pneumopericardium. It is a crunching or clicking sound which is synchronous with the heartbeat, best heard in the left lateral decubitus position.

Hoover’s sign is the paradoxical inward movement of the rib cage with inspiration in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Westermark sign is seen in chest radiographs of patients with pulmonary embolism, indicating focal oligemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female came to OPD with complaints of backache. On examination, Schober test was positive and her eyes and nose were hyperpigmented. Probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Given X-ray shows intervertebral disc calcification and hyperpigmentation of nose and eyes are present. Both features are indicative of ochronosis as diagnosis.

  • Ochronosis also known as alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is due to deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase leading to accumulation of homogentisic acid.
  • Clinical features: Triad of
    • Homogentisic aciduria (urine turns dark color on standing due to oxidation or alkalinisation)
    • Eumelanin like pigmentation of skin, sclera, cartilages etc.
    • Degenerative chronic arthropathies especially of spine, hip, knees.

Option a: Hypoparathyroidism doesn't explain hyperpigmentation and other clinical features of hypoparathyroidism aren't mentioned.

Option b: Fluorosis - dental symptoms are not mentioned and osteoporosis will be marked in case of fluorosis. Also, hyperpigmentation is not a typical feature of fluorosis.

Option d: Ankylosing spondylitis – females are unlikely to be affected and it doesn’t explain hyperpigmentation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents with bilateral proptosis. The biopsy from the region shows this pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and biopsy picture is characteristic of schwannoma.

The biopsy specimen in schwannoma shows hypocellular (Antoni B) and hypercellular areas (Antoni A). Antoni A area has the nuclei of tumor cells aligned in palisading rows. The nuclear-free zones that lie between nuclear palisading are known as Verocay bodies.

The histological section of a schwannoma showing Antoni A, Antoni B and Verocay bodies is given below:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HPE image?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages 
    • Abundant cytoplasm
    • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis 
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages 
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells

questions.text:
A patient presents with fever, headache, and cough with scanty sputum. His chest radiograph shows patchy consolidation of the left lower lobe. The culture of the sputum specimen shows fried egg colonies. Which of the following statements are true regarding the causative organism?
  1. It can be cultured on PPLO broth.
  2. It has a rigid cell wall composed of polysaccharides.
  3. It belongs to the class Mollicutes
  4. The colonies can be demonstrated by Diene’s stain
  5. It utilizes glucose or arginine as the major source of energy.
questions.solution:
The causative organism based on the given clinical scenario showing fried egg colonies on culture points to Mycoplasma pneumoniae. It is devoid of cell walls.

Mycoplasmas are the smallest microorganisms that are pleomorphic and lack cell walls. There are 4 species that are of importance to humans.

  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Mycoplasma hominis
  • Mycoplasma genitalium

Mycoplasmas, which belong to the class Mollicutes, derive their primary source of energy from glucose or arginine. Ureaplasmas are an exception as they have the capability to hydrolyze urea. To cultivate these bacteria, complex media like PPLO broth are employed, consisting of agar, broth, and biphasic media with enriching substances such as yeast dialysate and horse serum. Penicillin and thallium are added to prevent the growth of other bacteria.

Mycoplasma colonies exhibit a characteristic fried egg appearance, with a central opaque granular region that extends into the depth of the medium, surrounded by a flat, translucent outer zone. For a detailed examination, the Dienes method involves cutting a block of agar containing the colony and placing it on a slide. A cover slip is then applied, onto which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried.

These bacteria primarily cause pneumonia and genital infections. Ureaplasma urealyticum possesses a unique ability to hydrolyze urea and is responsible for non-gonococcal urethritis. It can exhibit resistance to commonly used antibiotics such as tetracycline and doxycycline.

The image given below shows fried-egg colonies of mycoplasma.

questions.text: Consider the following images (A and B) and pick the correct statement.

choices.text: In B, the earliest microscopic features would be aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses
In A, rectal involvement is always seen
In B, changes due to backwash ileitis are usually mild and superficial
In A, granulomas are rarely seen and are of little significance

questions.solution:
In the given images:

A - Crohn’s Disease (CD)

B – Ulcerative Colitis (UC)

questions.text: The following two diagnostic techniques (A) and (B) were performed in a medical camp conducted for diagnosing malaria. Which is a true statement regarding these techniques?

choices.text: Image (A) - It is used for identifying the species of the malarial parasite
Image (A) - It is not the established method of choice for diagnosing malaria in urban areas
Image (B) - Antibody detection by this test is the method of choice for diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas
Image (B) - Bivalent type of this test was used for detecting Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax

questions.solution:
Image (A) is a thick blood smear and Image (B) is the Rapid Diagnostic Test (RDT). Bivalent RDTs detect P. falciparum and P. vivax.

Thin blood smear is used to identify the particular infecting species. Thick blood smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration.

Antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) are not the method of choice anymore in diagnosing malaria in inaccessible and tribal areas. The Antigen detecting RDTs and blood smear examination are the recommended methods for diagnosis of malaria.

Note: According to the announcement by Union Health Ministry in April 2018, antibody detecting Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) for malaria is banned due to the high false-positive rates in endemic areas.

Malaria Antigen detecting Rapid Diagnostic Test kit:
